ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.0.2_0: Reverence to him, the Fortunate One, the Worthy One, the Perfect Sambuddha
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.1.1_0: At one time, soon after his awakening, the Buddha was staying at Uruvelā on the bank of the river Nerañjara at the foot of a Bodhi tree.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.1.2_0: There the Buddha sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.2.1_0: Then, in the first part of the night, the Buddha reflected on dependent origination in forward and reverse order:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.2.2_0: “Ignorance is a condition for intentional activities; intentional activities are a condition for consciousness; consciousness is a condition for name and form; name and form are a condition for the six sense spheres; the six sense spheres are a condition for contact; contact is a condition for feeling; feeling is a condition for craving; craving is a condition for grasping; grasping is a condition for existence; existence is a condition for birth; birth is a condition for old age and death, for grief, sorrow, pain, aversion, and distress to come to be.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.2.3_0: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.2.4_0: “But with the complete fading away and end of ignorance comes the end of intentional activities; with the end of intentional activities comes the end of consciousness; with the end of consciousness; with the end of name and form; with the end of name and form; with the end of the six sense spheres; with the end of the six sense spheres comes the end of contact; with the end of contact comes the end of feeling; with the end of feeling comes the end of craving; with the end of craving; with the end of grasping; with the end of existence comes the end of birth; with the end of birth; with the end of old age and death, and the end of sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and distress.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.2.5_0: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”’”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.3.1_0: Seeing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha exclaimed an inspired utterance:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.3.2_0: “When (the nature of) things becomes really manifest
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.3.5_0: since he understands each thing and its cause.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.4.1_0: In the middle part of the night, the Buddha again reflected on dependent origination in forward and reverse order:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.4.3_0: This is how there is the origin of this whole mass of suffering. ...
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.4.4_0: This is how there is the end of this whole mass of suffering.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.5.1_0: Seeing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha exclaimed an inspired utterance:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.5.2_0: “When (the nature of) things becomes really manifest
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.5.5_0: since he’s known the end of conditions.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.6.1_0: In the last part of the night, the Buddha again reflected on dependent origination in forward and reverse order:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.6.3_0: This is how there is the origin of this whole mass of suffering. ...
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.6.4_0: This is how there is the end of this whole mass of suffering.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.7.1_0: Seeing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha exclaimed an inspired utterance:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.7.2_0: “When (the nature of) things becomes really manifest
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.7.5_0: as the sun lights up the sky.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:1.7.6_0: The story at the Bodhi tree is finished.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:2.1.1_0: After seven days, the Buddha came out from that stillness and went from the Bodhi tree to a goat-herd’s banyan tree. There too he sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:2.2.1_0: Then a conceited brahmin approached the Buddha,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:2.2.3_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he stood to one side.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:2.2.5_0: “Good Gotama, how is one a brahmin? What are the things that make one a brahmin?”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:2.3.1_0: Seeing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha exclaimed an inspired utterance:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:2.3.3_0: Who is humble, free from flaws, and self-controlled,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:2.3.4_0: a complete knowledge master who has completed the spiritual journey—
ai-pli-tv-kd1:2.3.5_0: Righteously, without being full of himself,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:2.3.6_0: He may proclaim himself a brahmin.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:2.3.7_0: The story at the goat-herd’s banyan tree is finished.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:3.1.1_0: After seven days, the Buddha came out from that stillness and went from the goat-herd’s banyan tree to a powder-puff tree. There too he sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:3.2.1_0: Just then an unseasonal storm was approaching, with seven days of rain, cold winds, and clouds.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:3.2.2_0: Mucalinda, the dragon king, came out from his abode. And he encircled the body of the Buddha with seven coils and spread his large hood over his head, thinking,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:3.2.3_0: “May the Buddha not be hot or cold, nor be touched by horseflies or mosquitoes, by the wind or the burning sun, or by creeping animals and insects.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:3.3.1_0: After seven days, when he knew the sky was clear, Mucalinda unraveled his coils from the Buddha’s body and transformed himself into a young brahmin. He then stood in front of the Buddha, venerating him with joined palms raised.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:3.3.2_0: Seeing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha exclaimed an inspired utterance:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:3.4.1_0: “Seclusion is bliss for the contented one,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:3.4.2_0: who see the teaching they have learned.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:3.4.3_0: Kindness for the world is happiness
ai-pli-tv-kd1:3.4.4_0: who taskled creatures to living beings,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:3.4.5_0: Dispassion for the world is happiness
ai-pli-tv-kd1:3.4.7_0: But dispelling the conceit ʻI am’
ai-pli-tv-kd1:3.4.8_0: This, indeed, is the highest bliss.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:3.4.9_0: The story at the powder-puff tree is finished.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:4.1.1_0: After seven days, the Buddha came out from that stillness and went from the powder-puff tree to an ape-flower tree. There too he sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:4.2.1_0: Just then the merchants Tapussa and Bhallika were traveling from Ukkala to that area.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:4.2.2_0: Then a god who was a former relative of theirs said to them,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:4.2.3_0: “Sirs, a Buddha who has just attained awakening is staying at the foot of an ape-flower tree.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:4.2.4_0: Go to that Buddha and offer him baked goods and honey.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:4.2.5_0: That will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:4.3.1_0: And they took baked goods and honey and approached the Buddha. They bowed down
ai-pli-tv-kd1:4.3.3_0: “Venerable Sir, please accept the baked goods and honey from us. That will be to our benefit and happiness for a long time.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:4.4.3_0: In what should I receive the baked goods and honey?”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:4.4.4_0: reading the mind of the Buddha, the four great kings offered him four stone bowls from the four directions, saying,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:4.4.5_0: “Here, Sir, please receive the baked goods and honey in these.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:4.4.6_0: After receiving the baked goods and honey in one of the valuable stone bowls, the Buddha ate them.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:4.5.1_0: Knowing that the Buddha had laid down their handshoping brown, they said,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:4.5.2_0: “Sir, we take refuge in the Buddha and the Teaching. Please accept us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:4.5.3_0: By means of the double refuge, they became the first lay followers in the world.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:4.5.4_0: The story at the ape-flower tree is finished.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.1.1_0: After seven days, the Buddha came out from that stillness and went from the ape-flower tree to a goat-herd’s banyan tree,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.1.2_0: and there the Fortunate One dwelt at the root of the Goatherd’s Banyan (tree).
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.2.1_0: Then, while in seclusion, the Buddha thought this:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.2.2_0: “I have discovered this profound truth, so hard to see, so hard to comprehend. It’s peaceful and sublime, subtle, beyond the intellect, and knowable only to the wise.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.2.3_0: But people like attachment, they love it and enjoy it.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.2.4_0: and because of that it’s hard for them to see causal relationships, dependent origination.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.2.5_0: This too is very hard for them to see: the stilling of all intentional activities, the giving up of all ownership, the stopping of craving, fading away, ending, extinguishment.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.2.6_0: “If I were to teach the Dhamma, others might not understand me, which would be wearying and troublesome for me.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.3.1_0: And spontaneously, these verses never heard before occurred to the Buddha:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.3.3_0: enough with trying to explain it!
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.3.4_0: This teaching is not easily understood
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.3.5_0: by those mired in greed and hate.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.3.6_0: Those who are excited by sensual desire,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.3.7_0: what’s subtle, going against the stream,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.3.8_0: deep, hard to see, and very fine,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.3.9_0: What’s subtle and refined, profound and hard to see.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.4.1_0: And as the Buddha reflected like this, his mind inclined to remaining passive, not to teaching the Dhamma.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.4.2_0: Just then the supreme being Sahampati read the mind of the Buddha. And he thought,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.4.3_0: “The world is lost; it’s perished!—for the Buddha, perfected and fully awakened, inclines to inaction, and not to teaching.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.5.1_0: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the bank of the Sahampati and reappeared in the presence of the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.5.1_1: so did he vanish from the Brahmā realm and appear in front of the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.6.1_0: He put his upper robe over one shoulder, placed his right knee on the ground, raise his joined palms, and said,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.6.2_0: “Sir, let the Blessed One teach the Dhamma! Let the Holy One teach the Dhamma!
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.6.3_0: There are beings with little dust in their eyes who are ruined because of not hearing the Teaching. There will be those who understand.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.7.1_0: This is what Sahampati said, and he added:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.7.3_0: an impure Dhamma, invented by those still stained,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.7.4_0: Open this door to the deathless!
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.7.5_0: Let them hear the teaching the immaculate one discovered.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.7.6_0: Standing high on a rocky mountain,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.7.7_0: you can see the people all around.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.7.8_0: In just the same way, all-seer, wise one,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.7.9_0: the Palace made from Dhamma, Visionary One,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.7.10_0: Being rid of sorrow, look upon the people,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.7.11_0: Sunk in grief, overcome by birth and old age.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.7.12_0: Rise up, O Hero, Victorious in Battle.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.7.13_0: Caravan-Leader, Debtless One, travel through the world.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.7.14_0: Let the Blessed One teach the Dhamma!
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.7.15_0: There will be those who understand.”

ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.10.1_0: The Buddha understood the request of that supreme being, and because he had compassion for the world, he surveyed the world with the eye of a Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.11.1_0: And the Buddha saw sentient beings with little dust in their eyes, and some with much dust in their eyes; with keen faculties and with weak faculties, with good qualities and with bad qualities, easy to teach and hard to teach. And some of them lived seeing the danger in the fault to do with the next world, while others did not.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.11.2_0: It’s like a pool with blue water lilies, or pink or white lotuses.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.11.3_0: In the same way, the Buddha saw sentient beings with little dust in their eyes, and some with much dust in their eyes.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.12.1_0: When he had seen this, the Buddha replied to Sahampati in verse:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.12.2_0: “Flung open are the doors to the deathless!
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.12.3_0: whoever has ears let them release their faith.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.12.4_0: Perceiving trouble, Brahmā, I did not speak amongst humans,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.12.5_0: the sophisticated, sublime Dhamma among humans.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.13.2_0: “The Buddha has consented to teach.” He bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and disappeared right there.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:5.13.3_0: The account of the supreme being’s request is finished.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.1.2_0: “Who should I teach first of all?
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.1.3_0: Who will understand this Teaching quickly?”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.1.5_0: “That Āḷāra Kālāma is astute, competent, clever, and has long had little dust in his eyes.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.1.6_0: Perhaps I should teach him first. He will understand this Teaching quickly.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.2.1_0: But an invisible god informed the Buddha, “Sir, Ālāra Kālāma died seven days ago,”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.2.2_0: and the Buddha also knew this for himself.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.2.5_0: for if he had heard this Teaching he would have understood it quickly.”

ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.3.3_0: Who will understand this Teaching quickly?”

ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.3.6_0: Perhaps I should teach him first. He will understand this Teaching quickly.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.4.1_0: But an invisible god informed the Buddha, “Sir, Udaka Rāmaputta died last night,”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.4.2_0: and the Buddha also knew this for himself.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.4.5_0: for if he had heard this Teaching he would have understood it quickly.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.5.2_0: “Who should I teach first of all?
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.5.3_0: Who will understand this Teaching quickly?”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.5.5_0: “The group of five mendicants were very helpful to me. They looked after me during my time of resolute striving.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.6.1_0: Perhaps I should teach them first.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.6.3_0: But where are they staying now?”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.6.4_0: And with superhuman and purified clairvoyance, the Buddha saw that the group of five monks were staying near Benares, in the dear park at Isipatana.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.6.5_0: Then, after staying at Uruvelā for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Benares.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.7.1_0: The Ājīvaka ascetic Upaka saw the Buddha traveling between Gayā and the place of awakening. And he said to the Buddha,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.7.3_0: Who have you gone forth under?
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.7.5_0: or whose teaching do you believe in?”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.8.1_0: The Buddha replied to Upaka in verse:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.8.3_0: Undefiled in regard to all things,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.8.4_0: I’ve given up all, freed in the ending of craving.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.8.5_0: having deep knowledge myself, who should I point to (as Teacher)?
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.8.7_0: apart from the great sage himself.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.8.8_0: In the world with its gods,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:6.8.14_0: I’m going to the city of Kāsi,

ai-pli-tv-kd1:21.4.2_0: They are repelled by the ear, repelled by sounds, repelled by ear-consciousness, repelled by ear-contact, repelled by whatever feelings arise because of ear-contact—whether pleasant, painful, or neither-pleasant-nor-painful.

ai-pli-tv-kd1:22.10.4_0: ‘Venerable Sir, when I was a prince, I had these five wishes, and they have now been fulfilled.

ai-pli-tv-kd1:23.1.0_0: The account of the going forth of Sāriputta and Moggallāna
ai-pli-tv-kd1:23.1.1_0: At that time the wanderer Sañcaya was staying at Rājagaha with a large group of two hundred and fifty wanderers,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:23.1.3_0: and there was an agreement amongst themselves:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:23.1.4_0: that whoever reached the deathless first would inform the other.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:23.2.1_0: Just then, Venerable Assaji robed up in the morning, took his bowl and robe, and entered Rājagaha for almsfood. He inspired confidence in the way he entered and returned, in his looking at and looking away, in his drawing in and stretching out of his arms; his eyes were lowered, and he was perfect in deportment.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:23.2.2_0: The wanderer Sāriputta observed all this
ai-pli-tv-kd1:23.2.4_0: “This monk is among those in the world who are perfected or on the path to perfection.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:23.2.5_0: Let me approach him and ask him
ai-pli-tv-kd1:23.2.6_0: who he has gone forth under, who his teacher is, and whose teachings he follows.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:23.3.2_0: “It’s the wrong time to ask him while he’s walking for almsfood among the houses.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:23.3.3_0: Why don’t I follow behind him and caught up with them?”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:23.3.4_0: After walking for almsfood in Rājagaha, Assaji took his almsfood and turned back.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:23.3.5_0: Sāriputta then approached him and exchanged pleasantries with him.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:23.3.8_0: In whose name have you gone forth, reverend? Who is your Teacher? Whose teaching do you believe in?”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:23.4.1_0: “There is, reverend, the Great Ascetic, I gone forth from the Sakyan clan, I’ve gone forth from the Buddha. That teacher is his teaching.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:23.4.3_0: “I’m junior, good sir, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training. I’m not able to teach it in brief.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:23.4.7_0: But do tell me the meaning.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:23.4.9_0: For what’s the point of a detailed exposition?”

ai-pli-tv-kd1:24.7.12_0: The account of the going forth of Sāriputta and Moggallāna is finished.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:24.7.13_0: The fourth section for recitation is finished.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.1.1_0: At that time the monks did not have preceptors or teachers, and as a result they were not being instructed. While walking for almsfood, they were shabbily dressed and improper in appearance.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.1.2_0: While people were eating, they held out their almsbowls to receive leftovers, even right over their food, whether it was staple food, non-staple food, delicacies, or drinks.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.1.3_0: They ate bean curry and rice that they themselves had asked for,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.1.4_0: and they were noisy in the dining hall.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.2.1_0: People complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.2.2_0: “How can the Sakyan ascetics act like this?
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.2.3_0: People eat staple food, they’ll staple food on the leftovers, even their almsbowls, whether they’re staple food, delicayed.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.2.4_0: They eat rice and bean curry that they themselves have asked for,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.2.5_0: And even the brahmins will live in the dining hall like food.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.3.1_0: The monks heard the complaints of those people
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.3.2_0: The monks of few desires who had a sense of conscience, who were contented, afraid of wrongdoing, and fond of the training, complained and criticized Venerable Dhaniya,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.3.4_0: People eat staple food, they’ll staple food on the leftovers, even their almsbowls, whether they’re staple food, delicayed.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.3.5_0: They eat rice and bean curry that they themselves have asked for,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.3.6_0: and they’ll making a dreadful racket.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.4.3_0: Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.4.4_0: “Is it true, monks, that monks act like this?”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.5.2_0: It’s not suitable for those foolish men, it’s not proper, it’s not worthy of an ascetic, it’s not allowable, it’s not to be done.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.5.3_0: How can they act like this?
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.5.4_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it or increase the confidence of those who have it,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.5.5_0: but it will hinder confidence in those without it and it will cause some with confidence to change their minds.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.6.1_0: Then the Buddha spoke in many ways in dispraise of being difficult to support and maintain, in dispraise of great desires, discontent, socializing, and laziness; but he spoke in many ways in praise of being easy to support and maintain, of fewness of wishes, contentment, self-elimination, ascetic practices, serenity, reduction in things, and of being energetic. After giving a teaching on what is right and proper, he addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.6.2_0: “I allow a preceptor to visit a preceptor.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.6.3_0: The preceptor should regard his student as a son and the student his preceptor as a father.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.6.4_0: In this way they will respect, esteem, and be considerate toward each other, and they will grow and reach greatness on this spiritual path.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.7.1_0: And a preceptor should be chosen like this:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.7.2_0: After putting his upper robe over one shoulder, a student should pay respect at the feet of a potential preceptor. He should then squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.7.6_0: If the other makes it understood by body, by speech, or by body and speech: ‘Yes,’ or, ‘No problem,’ or, ‘It’s suitable,’ or, ‘It’s appropriate,’ or, ‘Carry on with inspiration’—then a preceptor has been chosen.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.7.7_0: If the other doesn’t make it understood by body, by speech, or by body and speech, then a preceptor hasn’t been chosen.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.8.1_0: A student should conduct himself properly toward his preceptor.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.8.3_0: After getting up at the appropriate time, the pupil should take off his sandals, and put his upper robe over one shoulder. He should then give his teacher a toothbrush and water for rinsing the mouth, and he should prepare a seat for him.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.8.4_0: If there is rice porridge, he should wash a vessel and bring the rice porridge to his preceptor.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.8.5_0: When the preceptor has drunk the rice porridge, the student should give him water and receive the vessel, and holding it low, he should wash it carefully without scratching it and then put it away.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.8.6_0: When the preceptor has gotten up, the student should put away the seat.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.8.7_0: If the place is dirty, he should sweep it.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.9.1_0: If the preceptor wants to enter the village, the student should give him a sarong and receive the one he’s wearing in return. He should give him a belt. He should put the upper robes together, overlapping each other edge-to-edge, and then give them to him. He should wash his preceptor’s bowl and then give it to him while wet.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.9.2_0: If the preceptor wants an attendant, the student should put on his sarong evenly all around, covering the navel and the knees. He should put on a belt. Putting the other upper together, overlapping each other edge-to-edge, he should put them on and fasten the toggle. After washing his bowl, he should take it with him and be his preceptor’s attendant.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.10.1_0: He shouldn’t walk too far behind his preceptor or too close to him. He should receive the contents of his bowl.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.10.2_0: He shouldn’t interrupt his preceptor when he’s speaking.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.10.3_0: But if the preceptor’s speech is bordering on an offense, he should stop him.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.10.4_0: When returning, the pupil should go first to prepare a seat and to set out a foot-stool, a foot-scraper, and water for washing the feet. He should go out to meet the teacher to receive his bowl and robe. He should give him a sarong and receive the one he’s wearing in return.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.10.5_0: If the robe is moist, he should sun it for a short while, but he shouldn’t leave it in the heat.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.10.6_0: offsetting the edges by seven centimeters,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.10.7_0: so that the fold doesn’t become worn.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.10.8_0: He should place the belt in the fold.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.10.9_0: If there is almsfood and his preceptor wants to eat, the student should give him water and then the almsfood.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.11.1_0: He should ask his preceptor if he wants water to drink.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.11.2_0: When the preceptor has eaten, the student should give him water and receive the bowl, and holding it low, he should wash it carefully without scratching it. He should then dry it and sun it for a short while, but he shouldn’t leave it in the heat.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.11.3_0: He should put away the bowl and robe.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.11.4_0: When putting away the bowl, he should hold the bowl in one hand, feel under the bed or the bench with the other, and then put it away.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.11.5_0: he should not put his bowl on the ground evenly on the ground.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.11.6_0: After taking hold of the robe-cloth with one hand and then puts it on the edge of the robe within arm’s reach of the other, he should put it on and put it aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.11.7_0: When the preceptor has gotten up, the student should put away the seat and also the foot-stool, the foot-scraper, and the water for washing the feet.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.11.8_0: If the place is dirty, he should sweep it.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.12.1_0: “If the preceptor wants to bathe, the student should prepare a bath.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.12.2_0: If he needs cold, he should prepare cold.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.12.3_0: if he wants a hot bath, he should prepare that.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.12.4_0: If the preceptor wants to use the sauna, the student should knead bath powder, moisten the clay, take the sauna stool, and follow behind his preceptor. After giving the preceptor the sauna stool, receiving his robe, and putting it aside, he should give him the bath powder and the clay.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.12.5_0: If he’s able, he should enter the sauna.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.12.6_0: When entering the sauna, he should smear his face with clay, cover himself in front and behind, and then enter the sauna.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.13.1_0: He shouldn’t sit encroaching on the senior monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.13.2_0: and he shouldn’t block the junior monks from getting a seat.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.13.3_0: While in the sauna, he should do services for his preceptor.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.13.4_0: When leaving the sauna, he should take the sauna stool, cover himself in front and behind, and then leave the sauna.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.13.5_0: He should also do services for his preceptor in the water.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.13.6_0: When he has bathed, he should be the first to come out of the water. He should dry himself and put on his sarong. He should then wipe the water off his preceptor’s body, and he should give him his sarong and then his upper robe. Taking the sauna stool, he should be the first to return. He should prepare a seat, as well as set out a foot-stool, a foot-scraper, and water for washing the feet. He should ask his bowl and robe,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.14.1_0: If the teacher wants him to recite, he should do so.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.14.2_0: If the preceptor wants to question him, he should be questioned.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.14.3_0: “If the dwelling where the preceptor is staying is dirty, the student should clean it if he’s able.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.14.4_0: When he is cleaning the dwelling, he should first take out the bowl and robe and put them aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.14.5_0: He should take out the sitting mat and the sheet and put them aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.14.6_0: He should take out the mattress and the pillow and put them aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.15.1_0: Holding the bed low, he should carefully take it out without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.15.2_0: Holding the bench low, he should carefully take it out without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.15.3_0: He should take out the bed supports and put them aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.15.4_0: He should take out the spit and put it aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.15.5_0: He should take out the leaning board and put it aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.15.6_0: After taking note of where it’s placed, he should take out the floor cover and put it aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.15.7_0: If the dwelling has cobwebs, he should first remove them from the ceiling cloth, and he should then wipe the windows and the corners of the room.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.15.8_0: If the walls have been treated with red ocher and they’re moldy, he should moisten a cloth, wring it out, and wipe the walls.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.15.9_0: If the floor has been treated with black and it’s moldy, he should moisten a cloth, wring it out, and wipe the floor.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.15.10_0: If the floor is untreated, he should sprinkle it with water and then sweep it,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.15.11_0: while trying to avoid stirring up dust.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.15.12_0: He should look out for any trash and discard it.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.16.1_0: He should sun the floor cover, clean it, beat it, bring it back inside, and put it back in the same place as before.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.16.2_0: He should sun the bed supports, wipe them, bring them back inside, and place them in the same position as before.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.16.3_0: He should sun the bed, clean it, and beat it. Holding it low, he should carefully bring it back inside without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it back in the same place as before.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.16.4_0: He should sun the bench, clean it, and beat it. Holding it low, he should carefully bring it back inside without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it back in the same place as before.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.16.5_0: He should sun the mattress and the pillow, clean them, beat them, bring them back inside, and put them back the way they were.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.16.6_0: He should sun the sitting mat and the sheet, clean them, beat them, bring them back inside, and put them back the way they were.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.16.7_0: He should sun the spittoon, wipe it, bring it back inside, and put it back where it was.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.16.8_0: He should sun the leaning board, wipe it, bring it back inside, and put it back where it was.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.17.1_0: He should put away the bowl and robe.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.17.2_0: When putting away the bowl, he should hold the bowl in one hand, feel under the bed or the bench with the other, and then put it away.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.17.3_0: he should not put his bowl on the ground evenly on the ground.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.17.4_0: After taking hold of the robe-cloth with one hand and then puts it on the edge of the robe within arm’s reach of the other, he should put it on and put it aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.18.1_0: If dusty winds are blowing from the east, he should close the windows on the eastern side.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.18.2_0: If dusty winds are blowing from the west, he should close the windows on the west.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.18.3_0: If dusty winds are blowing from the north, he should close the windows on the northern side.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.18.4_0: If dusty winds are blowing from the south, he should close the windows on the southern side.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.18.5_0: If the weather is cold, he should open the windows during the day and close them at night.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.18.6_0: If the weather is hot, he should close the windows during the day and open them at night.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.19.1_0: If the precincts are dirty, he should sweep them.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.19.2_0: If the gateway is dirty, he should sweep it.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.19.3_0: If the assembly hall is dirty, he should sweep it.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.19.4_0: If the water-boiling shed is dirty, he should sweep it.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.19.5_0: If the restroom is dirty, he should sweep it.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.19.6_0: If there is no water for drinking, he should set it out.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.19.7_0: If there is no water for washing, he should set it out.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.19.8_0: If there is no water in the rinsing pot, he should fill it.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.20.1_0: “If the preceptor becomes discontent, the student should send him away or have him sent away, or he should give him a teaching.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.20.2_0: If the preceptor becomes anxious, the student should dispel it or have it dispelled, or he should give him a teaching.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.20.3_0: If the preceptor has a wrong view, the student should make him give it up or get someone else to do it, or he should give him a teaching.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.21.1_0: If the preceptor has committed a heavy offense and deserves probation,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.21.2_0: the student should try for the Sangha to get it done.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.21.3_0: If the preceptor has committed a heavy offense and deserves to be sent back to the beginning,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.21.4_0: the student should try for the Sangha to get it done.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.21.5_0: If the preceptor has committed a heavy offense and deserves to be given the trial period,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.21.6_0: the student should try for the Sangha to get it done.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.21.7_0: If the preceptor has committed a heavy offense and deserves rehabilitation,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.21.8_0: the student should try for the Sangha to get it done.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.22.1_0: If the Sangha wants to do a legal procedure against his preceptor—whether a procedure of condemnation, demotion, banishment, reconciliation, or ejection—
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.22.2_0: the student should make an effort to stop it or to reduce the penalty.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.22.3_0: But if the Sangha has already done a legal procedure against his preceptor—whether a procedure of condemnation, demotion, banishment, reconciliation, or ejection—
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.22.4_0: the student should help the preceptor conduct himself properly and suitably so as to deserve to be released, and try for the Sangha to lift that procedure.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.23.1_0: “If the preceptor’s robe needs washing, the student should do it himself,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.23.2_0: he should make an effort or to have it done.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.23.3_0: If the preceptor needs a robe, the student should make one himself,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.23.4_0: or he should make an effort to have one made.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.23.5_0: If the preceptor needs dye, the student should make it himself,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.23.6_0: or he should make an effort to have it made.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.23.7_0: If the preceptor’s robe needs dyeing, the student should do it himself,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.23.8_0: or he should make an effort to have it done.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.23.9_0: When he’s dyeing the robe, he should carefully and repeatedly turn it over, and he shouldn’t go away while it’s still dripping.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.24.1_0: Without asking permission of his preceptor, he shouldn’t do any of the following: give away or receive a bowl;
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.24.2_0: give away or receive a robe;
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.24.3_0: give away or receive a requisite;
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.24.4_0: cut anyone’s hair or have it cut;
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.24.5_0: do work for anyone or have work done by anyone;
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.24.6_0: do a service for anyone or have a service done by anyone;
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.24.7_0: be the attendant monk for anyone or take anyone as his attendant monk;
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.24.8_0: bring back almsfood for anyone or have almsfood brought back by anyone;
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.24.12_0: If his preceptor is sick, he should nurse him for as long as he lives,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.24.13_0: should not go anywhere until you have recovered.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:25.24.14_0: The proper conduct toward the preceptor is finished.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.1.1_0: “And a preceptor should conduct himself properly toward his student.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.1.3_0: A preceptor should help and take care of his student through recitation, questioning, and instruction.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.1.4_0: If the preceptor has a bowl, but not the student, the preceptor should give it to him,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.1.5_0: or he should make an effort to get him one.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.1.6_0: If the preceptor has a robe, but not the student, the preceptor should give it to him,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.1.7_0: or he should make an effort to get him one.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.1.8_0: If the preceptor has a requisite, but not the student, the preceptor should give it to him,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.1.9_0: or he should make an effort to get him one.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.2.1_0: If the student is sick, the preceptor should get up at the appropriate time, and he should give his student a toothbrush and water for rinsing the mouth, and he should prepare a seat for him.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.2.2_0: If there is rice porridge, he should wash a vessel and bring the rice porridge to his preceptor.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.2.3_0: When the preceptor has drunk the rice porridge, the student should give him water and receive the vessel, and holding it low, he should wash it carefully without scratching it and then put it away.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.2.4_0: When the student has gotten up, the preceptor should put away the seat.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.2.5_0: If the place is dirty, he should sweep it.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.3.1_0: If the student wants to enter the village, the preceptor should give him a sarong and receive the one he’s wearing in return. He should give him a belt. He should put the upper robes together, overlapping each other edge-to-edge, and then give them to him. He should wash his student’s bowl and then give it to him while wet.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.3.2_0: Before he’s due back, the teacher should prepare a seat and set out a foot-stool, a foot-scraper, and water for washing the feet. He should go out to meet the pupil to receive his bowl and robe. He should give him a sarong and receive the one he’s wearing in return.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.3.3_0: If the robe is moist, he should sun it for a short while, but he shouldn’t leave it in the heat.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.3.4_0: offsetting the edges by seven centimeters,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.3.5_0: so that the fold doesn’t become worn.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.3.6_0: He should place the belt in the fold.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.3.7_0: If there is almsfood and his student wants to eat, the preceptor should give him water and then the almsfood.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.4.1_0: He should ask his student if he wants water to drink.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.4.2_0: When the preceptor has eaten, the student should give him water and receive the bowl, and holding it low, he should wash it carefully without scratching it. He should then dry it and sun it for a short while, but he shouldn’t leave it in the heat.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.4.3_0: He should put away the bowl and robe.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.4.4_0: When putting away the bowl, he should hold the bowl in one hand, feel under the bed or the bench with the other, and then put it away.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.4.5_0: he should not put his bowl on the ground evenly on the ground.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.4.6_0: After taking hold of the robe-cloth with one hand and then puts it on the edge of the robe within arm’s reach of the other, he should put it on and put it aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.4.7_0: When the student has gotten up, the preceptor should put away the seat and also the foot-stool, the foot-scraper, and the water for washing the feet.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.4.8_0: If the place is dirty, he should sweep it.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.5.1_0: “If the student wants to bathe, the preceptor should prepare the bath.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.5.2_0: If he needs cold, he should prepare cold.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.5.3_0: if he wants a hot bath, he should prepare that.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.5.4_0: If the student wants to use the sauna, the preceptor should knead bath powder, moisten the clay, take the sauna stool, and go to the sauna. After giving the student the sauna stool, receiving his robe, and putting it aside, he should give him the bath powder and the clay.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.5.5_0: If he’s able, he should enter the sauna.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.5.6_0: When entering the sauna, he should smear his face with clay, cover himself in front and behind, and then enter the sauna.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.6.1_0: He shouldn’t sit encroaching on the senior monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.6.2_0: and he shouldn’t block the junior monks from getting a seat.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.6.3_0: While in the sauna, he should do services for his student.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.6.4_0: When leaving the sauna, he should take the sauna stool, cover himself in front and behind, and then leave the sauna.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.6.5_0: The preceptor should also do services for his student in the water.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.6.6_0: When the preceptor has bathed, he should be the first to come out of the water. He should dry himself and put on his sarong. He should then wipe the water off his student’s body, and he should give him his sarong and then his upper robe.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.6.7_0: Taking the sauna stool, he should be the first to return. He should should prepare a seat, as well as set out a foot-stool, a foot-scraper, and water for washing the feet.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.6.8_0: He should ask his student if he wants water to drink.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.1_0: “If the dwelling where the student is staying is dirty, the preceptor should clean it if he’s able.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.2_0: When he is cleaning the dwelling, he should first take out the bowl and robe and put them aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.3_0: He should take out the sitting mat and the sheet and put them aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.4_0: He should take out the mattress and the pillow and put them aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.5_0: Holding the bed low, he should carefully take it out without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.6_0: Holding the bench low, he should carefully take it out without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.7_0: He should take out the bed supports and put them aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.8_0: He should take out the spit and put it aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.9_0: He should take out the leaning board and put it aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.10_0: After taking note of where it’s placed, he should take out the floor cover and put it aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.11_0: If the dwelling has cobwebs, he should first remove them from the ceiling cloth, and he should then wipe the windows and the corners of the room.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.12_0: If the walls have been treated with red ocher and they’re moldy, he should moisten a cloth, wring it out, and wipe the walls.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.13_0: If the floor has been treated with black and it’s moldy, he should moisten a cloth, wring it out, and wipe the floor.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.14_0: If the floor is untreated, he should sprinkle it with water and then sweep it,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.15_0: while trying to avoid stirring up dust.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.16_0: He should look out for any trash and discard it.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.17_0: He should sun the floor cover, clean it, beat it, bring it back inside, and put it back in the same place as before.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.18_0: He should sun the bed supports, wipe them, bring them back inside, and place them in the same position as before.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.19_0: He should sun the bed, clean it, and beat it. Holding it low, he should carefully bring it back inside without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it back in the same place as before.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.20_0: He should sun the bench, clean it, and beat it. Holding it low, he should carefully bring it back inside without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it back in the same place as before.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.21_0: He should sun the mattress and the pillow, clean them, beat them, bring them back inside, and put them back the way they were.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.22_0: He should sun the sitting mat and the sheet, clean them, beat them, bring them back inside, and put them back the way they were.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.23_0: He should sun the spittoon, wipe it, bring it back inside, and put it back where it was.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.24_0: He should sun the leaning board, wipe it, bring it back inside, and put it back where it was.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.25_0: He should put away the bowl and robe.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.26_0: When putting away the bowl, he should hold the bowl in one hand, feel under the bed or the bench with the other, and then put it away.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.27_0: he should not put his bowl on the ground evenly on the ground.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.28_0: After taking hold of the robe-cloth with one hand and then puts it on the edge of the robe within arm’s reach of the other, he should put it on and put it aside.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.29_0: If dusty winds are blowing from the east, he should close the windows on the eastern side.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.30_0: If dusty winds are blowing from the west, he should close the windows on the west.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.31_0: If dusty winds are blowing from the north, he should close the windows on the northern side.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.32_0: If dusty winds are blowing from the south, he should close the windows on the southern side.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.33_0: If the weather is cold, he should open the windows during the day and close them at night.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.34_0: If the weather is hot, he should close the windows during the day and open them at night.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.35_0: If the precincts are dirty, he should sweep them.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.36_0: If the gateway is dirty, he should sweep it.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.37_0: If the assembly hall is dirty, he should sweep it.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.38_0: If the water-boiling shed is dirty, he should sweep it.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.39_0: If the restroom is dirty, he should sweep it.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.40_0: If there is no water for drinking, he should set it out.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.41_0: If there is no water for washing, he should set it out.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.7.42_0: If there is no water in the rinsing pot, he should fill it.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.8.1_0: “If the student becomes discontent, the preceptor should send him away or have him sent away, or he should give him a teaching.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.8.2_0: If the student becomes anxious, the preceptor should dispel it or have it dispelled, or he should give him a teaching.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.8.3_0: If the student has a wrong view, the preceptor should make him give it up or get someone else to do it, or he should give him a teaching.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.9.1_0: If the student has committed a heavy offense and deserves probation,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.9.2_0: the preceptor should try for the Sangha to get it done.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.9.3_0: If the student has committed a heavy offense and deserves to be sent back to the beginning,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.9.4_0: the preceptor should try for the Sangha to get it done.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.9.5_0: If the student has committed a heavy offense and deserves to be given the trial period,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.9.6_0: the preceptor should try for the Sangha to get it done.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.9.7_0: If the student has committed a heavy offense and deserves rehabilitation,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.9.8_0: the preceptor should try for the Sangha to get it done.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.10.1_0: If the Sangha wants to do a legal procedure against his student—whether a procedure of condemnation, demotion, banishment, reconciliation, or ejection—
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.10.2_0: the preceptor should make an effort to stop it or to reduce the penalty.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.10.3_0: But if the Sangha has already done a legal procedure against his student—whether a procedure of condemnation, demotion, banishment, reconciliation, or ejection—
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.10.4_0: the preceptor should help the student conduct himself properly and suitably so as to deserve to be released, and try for the Sangha to lift that procedure.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.11.1_0: “If the student’s robe needs washing, the preceptor should show him how to do it,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.11.2_0: or he should make an effort to have it done.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.11.3_0: If the student needs a robe, the preceptor should show him how to make one,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.11.4_0: or he should make an effort to have one made.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.11.5_0: If the student needs dye, the preceptor should show him how to make it,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.11.6_0: or he should make an effort to have it made.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.11.7_0: If the student’s robe needs dyeing, the preceptor should show him how to do it,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.11.8_0: or he should make an effort to have it done.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.11.9_0: When he’s dyeing the robe, he should carefully and repeatedly turn it over,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.11.10_0: If the senior monk should not leave, he shouldn’t go.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.11.11_0: If his student is sick, he should nurse him for as long as he lives, or he should wait until he has recovered.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:26.11.12_0: The proper conduct toward a student is finished.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.1.1_0: On a later occasion the students did not conduct themselves properly toward their preceptors.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.1.2_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.1.3_0: “How can students not conduct themselves properly toward their preceptors?”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.1.4_0: They then told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned them:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.1.5_0: “Is it true, monks, that students are acting like this?”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.1.8_0: “... How can students not conduct themselves properly toward their preceptors?” ...
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.1.10_0: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.1.11_0: “A student should conduct himself properly toward his preceptor.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.1.12_0: If he doesn’t, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.2.1_0: They still did not conduct themselves properly.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.2.3_0: “You should dismiss one who doesn’t conduct himself properly.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.2.4_0: And this is how he should be dismissed.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.2.5_0: If the preceptor makes it understood by body, by speech, or by body and speech: ʻI dismiss you,’ or, ʻDon’t come back here,’ or, ʻRemove your bowl and robe,’ or, ʻYou shouldn’t attend on me’—then the student has been dismissed.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.2.6_0: If he doesn’t make it understood by body, speech, or by body and speech, then the student hasn’t been dismissed.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.3.1_0: Students who had been dismissed did not ask for forgiveness.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.3.4_0: They still did not ask for forgiveness.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.3.7_0: If he doesn’t, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.4.1_0: Preceptors who were asked for forgiveness did not forgive.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.4.4_0: They still did not ask for forgiveness.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.4.5_0: The students left, disrobed, and joined the ascetics of other religions.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.4.7_0: When asked for forgiveness, you should forgive.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.4.8_0: If you don’t, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.5.1_0: Preceptors dismissed students who were conducting themselves properly and did not dismiss those who were not.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.5.4_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.5.5_0: And you should dismiss someone who isn’t conducting himself properly.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.5.6_0: If you don’t, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.6.1_0: “If a student has five qualities, he should be dismissed.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.6.2_0: He doesn’t have much affection for his preceptor; he doesn’t have much confidence in his preceptor; he doesn’t have a strong sense of conscience in regard to his preceptor; he doesn’t have much respect for his preceptor; he hasn’t developed his mind much under his preceptor.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.6.4_0: If a student has five qualities, he shouldn’t be dismissed.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.6.5_0: The student has much affection for his preceptor; he has much confidence in his preceptor; he has a strong sense of conscience in regard to his preceptor; he has much respect for his preceptor; he has developed his mind much under his preceptor.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.6.6_0: If a student has these five qualities, he shouldn’t be dismissed.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.7.1_0: If a student has five qualities, he deserves to be dismissed.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.7.2_0: He doesn’t have much affection for his preceptor; he doesn’t have much confidence in his preceptor; he doesn’t have a strong sense of conscience in regard to his preceptor; he doesn’t have much respect for his preceptor; he hasn’t developed his mind much under his preceptor.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:27.7.3_0: If a student has these five qualities, he deserves to be dismissed.

ai-pli-tv-kd1:28.1.1_0: On one occasion a brahmin approached the monks and asked for the going forth,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:28.1.3_0: As a result, he became thin, haggard, and pale, his veins protruding all over his limbs.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:28.1.4_0: The Buddha saw him, and he asked the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:28.1.5_0: “Why is that brahmin looking so sickly?”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:28.1.6_0: And they told him what had happened.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:28.1.8_0: As a result, he became thin, haggard, and pale, his veins protruding all over his limbs.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:28.2.1_0: The Buddha said to the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:28.2.2_0: “Does anyone remember any act of service from that brahmin?”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:28.2.6_0: “While I was walking for almsfood here in Rājagaha, that brahmin gave a ladleful of food.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:28.2.7_0: I remember this act of service.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:28.3.1_0: “Good, good, Sāriputta, superior people have gratitude.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:28.3.2_0: Well then, Sāriputta, give that brahmin the going forth and the full ordination.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:28.3.4_0: After giving a teaching, the Buddha addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:28.3.5_0: “From today I rescind the full ordination of going for refuge three times.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:28.4.1_0: Instead you should give the full ordination through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:28.4.2_0: And the ordination should be done like this.

ai-pli-tv-kd1:28.4.4_0: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:28.4.5_0: So-and-so wants the full ordination with Venerable so-and-so.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:28.4.6_0: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should give her the full ordination with so-and-so as his preceptor.

ai-pli-tv-kd1:28.5.4_0: Any monk who approves of giving the full ordination to so-and-so with so-and-so as his preceptor should remain silent.

ai-pli-tv-kd1:28.6.8_0: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”

ai-pli-tv-kd1:29.1.3_0: “Please don’t do that; it’s not allowable.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:29.1.5_0: “But I didn’t ask you to ordain me.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:29.1.8_0: “You should not give the full ordination to anyone without an almsbowl.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:29.1.9_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:29.1.10_0: I allow you to give the full ordination to someone when you have been asked.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:29.2.1_0: And you should be asked like this.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:29.2.2_0: After approaching the Sangha, the one who wants the full ordination should put his upper robe over one shoulder and pay respect at the feet of the monks. He should then squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say:

ai-pli-tv-kd1:29.2.4_0: And he should ask a second

ai-pli-tv-kd1:30.1.1_0: At that time in Rājagaha, there was a succession of fine meals.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:30.1.3_0: “These Sakyan ascetics, however, have pleasant habits and a happy life. After eating nice food, they sleep in beds sheltered from the wind.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:30.1.4_0: Let me go forth with the Sakyan ascetics.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:30.1.5_0: Then that brahmin approached the monks and asked for the going forth.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:30.1.6_0: The monks gave him the going forth and the full ordination,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:30.2.1_0: When he had gone forth, that succession of meals came to a stop.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:30.2.5_0: “I didn’t go forth to walk for almsfood.
ai-pli-tv-kd1:30.2.6_0: If you give me some, I’ll eat it. If not, I’ll disrobe.”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:30.2.7_0: “But did you go forth for the sake of your stomach?”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:30.3.1_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
ai-pli-tv-kd1:30.3.2_0: “How can a monk go forth on this well-proclaimed spiritual path for the sake of your stomach?”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:30.3.3_0: They told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned that monk:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:30.3.4_0: “Is it true, monk, that you went forth for the sake of our stomach?”
ai-pli-tv-kd1:30.3.7_0: “... Foolish man, how can you go forth on this well-proclaimed spiritual path for the sake of your stomach?
ai-pli-tv-kd1:30.3.8_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...
ai-pli-tv-kd1:30.3.10_0: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd1:30.4.1_0: “When you have been asked, you should give him the full ordination:
